CSS Units of measure

Which one is the best? Let's find out!

  • px
  • em
  • rem
  • %

px

Pixels are fixed-size units.

Don't let the name fool you, pixels have little to do with the pixels on your screen. They are actually considered an non-linear angular measurement.

use for:

  • fixed widths and heights
  • setting a max-width on containers
  • setting media queries
  • fine-grained control

examples

Here are two examples of where I use pixels the most:

em

An em is a unit of measure that is relative to the current font size.

Set the base font size in the body tag to take advantage of em's responsive capabilities. Remember, 1em is equal to 100% of the base font size, so 1.5em is 150% etc.

use for:

  • easily changing your base font size in one place
  • flexible responsive web design
  • reserving an amount of space relative to your current base font-size
  • maintaing the relationship between font size and margin/padding

examples

I set my base font-size to 125% or 20px with a line-height of 1.5em. I like my fonts readable!

rem

Parent

A parent element is an element that contains other elements.

Child

All elements that are contained within that parent are called "child" elements.

In this tutorial, we are going to look at how positioning will change the relationship between parent and child elements.
